rep_number: 2 sites had measurements of individual trees, N not given

missing_something_major: may or may not belong in the table…
notes: Not really a gorwth phenology staudy they were looking at thinning treatments, but more days of growth = more growth. growth never stopped at one site, just slowed over winter

rep_number: 10 trees for phenology; 17 for tree ring
missing_something_major: I just wish they had more reps and more sites or looked at something different but 20 years of data is a lot and pretty darn good!
notes: they found warmer spring temperatures led to earlier SOS, warmer fall temps led later EOS. Warmer spring temps decreased growth but more precip and soil water availability increased growth

species_list: Quercus robur, Quercus petraea and Fagus sylvatica
study_scale: 5 years over 35 populations, representing >1200 dominant and co-dominant trees of three species
authorsthink_evidence_gslxgrowth_notsure: it's more about phenological rank than actual growing season length
ifyouthink_no_why: it's not about the actual GSL, it's about the phenological rank - so finding relationships between earlier budburst or later leafout but not full GSL
excellent_study: nah - it's not exactly related to what we're looking at
missing_something_major: They're more interested in phenological ranks and how earlier leafout species take advantage of early spring resources and grow more and then later leafout species have end of season resources and grow more but individuals that have longer GLS don't show evidence of more growth

study_scale: 54 individuals from 16 genotypes with latitudinal gradient over latitude 49-56
youthink_evidence_gslxgrowth_notsure: I think it's likely but impossible to know for sure without more details on budburst
ifyes_whichendogenous: no for latitude and bud burst timing and lammas are not realted to growth allocation, early buds = height, late buds = more roots
excellent_study: no - it doesn't tell us the actual growing season length, more focuses on end of season. It only assesses one species and doesn't look at multiple years
big_problems: Was very hard to figure out whether early or late buds = more growth or just different allocation
missing_something_major: more information on start of growth
notes_specific_columns: for the authors think suitable days or start to end column, it's not clear if the GSL is actually longer or if they're just looking at budset dates

study_scale: 9 populations along an elevational gradient of 1500 m in the French
study_level: across sites/populations across years within individuals
authorsthink_evidence_gslxgrowth_notsure: yes high elevation, negative association low elevation
authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: yes - for temperature x latitude relationships with radial growth
ifyouthink_no_why: there's no relationship between phenology and radial growth
authorsfoundevidencefor_endogenousfactor: individual trees had internally consistent timing
excellent_study: pretty close - it would be great if they had more species and across more locations
notes: they found no relationship between phenology and radial growth but they found that higher temps at higher elevations lead to increased radial growth, whereas higher temps at lower elevations decreased growth, likely due to water availability, seem to have used nlme models but do not say where or what form, took partial derivative of their mixed model, but don't say with respect to what X

study_scale: 35 provenances across Canada (full species range), 2 common gardens southern canada
authorsthink_evidence_gslxgrowth_suitabl: correlation between height growth duration and height
authorslooked_endogenousfactors:
growth_metric: subset of individuals harvested for biomass - very hard to tell which they meant throughout when referencing growth especially in the difference between sites.   authorsthink_evidence_gslbygrowth: so this was weird, height was correlated with duration of height growth
But biomass growth was highest at the site with fewer GDD and shorter height growth duration.   authorsthink_teststatistic: relationship between GDD and biomass was really a difference between the 2 gardens not directly attributed to GDD
